title: The £13 buy mums swear by to stop their kids getting nits
description: MUMS have been raving about a £13 buy that stops kids from getting nits. With the kids going back to school this week, after six long weeks off, many parents are likely to notice that their kids co…
content:
MUMS have been raving about a £13 buy that stops kids from getting nits.

With the kids going back to school this week, after six long weeks off, many parents are likely to notice that their kids come home with little critters in their hair.

September is usually the worst time of year for nits, as when children go back to school, they have increased exposure with other kids.

Although nits are not harmful to kids, they can cause itchiness and irritation, and can easily be passed on to the whole family.

The tiny creatures can be incredibly difficult to get rid of, but one mum has revealed a £13 solution, that should stop them from getting on to your child's head.

Posting to TikTok, a mum named @hannahsfamilylife, revealed that she was making a DIY nit potion, from tea tree oil, a carrier oil and water.

There is no conclusive evidence to suggest that tea tree oil can prevent nits, so TikTokers raced to the video's comments section to share alternative methods.

One mum said: "I used Nitty Gritty on my sons hair and he didn't catch nits.

"Definitely a good idea to try and prevent it."

Nitty Gritty Conditioning Head Lice Defence Spray is priced at £12.99, and was created by mums, to stop head lice from taking over kids' heads.

Head lice use their sense of smell to detect a new head to climb on to, so Nitty Gritty works by masking the scent of hair, to create an unappealing environment for the lice.

To use the eco-friendly product, simply spritz it on to your child's head every morning before school or nursery.

Nitty Gritty said: "We recommend daily use of our Nitty Gritty Conditioning Defence Spray to keep those pesky lice from crawling back on to your little one’s heads.

"It's a carefully chosen blend of ingredients with a lovely grapefruit scent, that smells great to us, but not so great to head lice!

"It not only keeps those pesky lice at bay but keeps everyone's hair fragranced, soft, shiny, de-tangled and in tip-top condition."

How to prevent an outbreak of nits THE Hairforce’s Dee Wright shares her top tips to nip a nit outbreak in the bud. GO PUBLIC: Nits are not a dirty secret. If you tell other parents you’ve found lice, they know to do an extra check on their own kids and catch them before they get out of control. GET A NIT CHECK ROUTINE IN PLACE: Make a “nit check” part of your weekly routine. Use a good-quality nit comb, like Nitty Gritty nit comb, inset, £8.52 reduced from £13, at Amazon. DO EXTRA CHECKS AFTER NIT “DANGER POINTS”: If your child has been at an event where they have been closer than usual to other children, do an extra head check. Events such as school trips, parties and sleepovers are all ideal breeding grounds for head lice. DON’T TAKE SHORTCUTS: When you buy a product to treat lice, make sure you follow the instructions carefully. Don’t neglect doing a second treatment a week later, even if you can’t see any signs of eggs. This is how lice cases get out of control. IT’S NOT ONLY YOUNG KIDS: People often only check their primary school-aged children for head lice, but older children and adults can bring them into the home too. It is important that the whole family checks their hair every week.

The Nitty Gritty website is flooded with reviews from satisfied parents, who have rated the product five stars.

One mum said: "My daughter has long hair and using the spray is part of our morning routine before school. Year 5 now and no nits.

"It's the one thing I recommend to friends for their family."

A second person said: "Since I started using this well over 2 years ago my daughter has never got nits."

A third person said: "Bought at the start of an outbreak at school.

"So far seems to be working!"
